metadata.title: Mesoporous covalent organic framework: An active photo-catalyst for formic acid synthesis through carbon dioxide reduction under visible light

Table 2 Catalytic activity study for the recycled catalyst. a Table 2 Entry No. of Cycles TON b 1 1st 125 2 2nd 125 3 3rd 124 4 4th 122 5 5th 121 a Reactions were carried out for 4 h with 1 atm CO2 balloon in 5 mL acetonitrile, 0.133 mL TEOA unless otherwise noted. b Calculated by using a calibration plot in UV–vis spectrometer. Mesoporous covalent organic framework: An active photo-catalyst for formic acid synthesis through carbon dioxide reduction under visible light Priyanka Sarkar a Sk. Riyajuddin b 1 Anjan Das a 1 Arpita Hazra Chowdhury a Kaushik Ghosh b Sk. Manirul Islam a * a Department of Chemistry, University of Kalyani, Kalyani, Nadia, West Bengal, India Department of Chemistry University of Kalyani Nadia Kalyani West Bengal India Department of Chemistry, University of Kalyani, Kalyani, Nadia, West Bengal, India b Institute of Nano Science and Technology, Mohali, 160062 India Institute of Nano Science and Technology Mohali 160062 India Institute of Nano Science and Technology, Mohali, 160062 India ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 authors contributed equally Graphical abstract We demonstrate the photocatalytic reduction of CO2 into HCOOH using mesoporous Covalent Organic Framework (COF) as the active photocatalyst, Co(dmg)2 as co-catalyst with Triethanolamine (TEOA) as sacrificial electron source under atmospheric pressure. Greater than 125 TON is achieved with 10 mg catalyst. The reaction cycle is dependent on the use of co-catalyst, Co(dmg)2 and sacrificial electron donor (TEOA). The reaction does not occur in the absence of light (445 nm) and can readily be controlled by light intensity alternation. We also demonstrate that a TON of 36 can be obtained with use of sunlight using the catalytic cycle. These results open the door to an entirely new class of protocol for photocatalytic reduction of CO2 using COF and Co(dmg)2 as co-catalyst under visible light. Keywords Photocatalysis Covalent organic framework Carbon dioxide Formic acid Photoreductions 1 Introduction Increasing environmental concerns in recent years for global warming, climate change, and ocean acidification are motivating researchers around the world for developing efficient and green strategies to capture, store, and utilize CO2 [1–5]. Again, in the viewpoint of chemistry, CO2 is one of most abundant, inexpensive and renewable carbon feedstock for producing value-added organic compounds and fuels [6–17]. So, the research on chemical transformations of CO2 into fuels and essential chemicals are increasing day by day to reduce the CO2 concentration in the atmosphere. Driving reactions by using a sustainable, green and eco-friendly process is a great challenge for modern scientific community [18–20]. Consequently, it has become imperative for chemists to find new technologies capable of transforming undesirable CO2 to useful chemicals, which are energetically efficient. One of the best means is the use of solar energy for the photochemical reduction of CO2 in terms of abundant and sustainable source of energy [21–30]. There are reports available for the photo reduction of CO2 using metal oxide, such as TiO2 under UV radiation [31–35] and also chemical reduction of CO2 to formic acid [36,37]. However, the majority of the sun's rays fall under the visible-IR range, which is not enough to photoreduce CO2 with these materials limiting their applicability and scalability. Thus, photoactive materials that are able to reduce CO2 under visible light are an imminent and currently unavoidable need. In this context, covalent organic frameworks (COFs) have recently emerged as a new class of photoactive materials for light-induced CO2 reduction [38–42]. Although, COFs are similar to related polymeric carbon nitrides, they modular, versatile and have easy tunable electronic properties, structure, crystallinity and porosity. Additionally COFs are completely composed of light elements, which are earth-abundant leading to synthetically versatile heterogeneous photocatalysis [43–45]. The highly efficient light harvesting and charge transport capability of COFs presumably arises from the π-electron conjugation in plane together along with the possibility of axial charge transport in the stacking direction by the overlap of π-orbitals [46–49]. However, it is highly surprising that despite their enormous potential, COFs have hardly been explored as visible light active photocatalysts for the production of solar fuels. Recently some work on photocatalytic reduction of CO2 to fuels and various chemicals using COFs as active photocatalysts have been reported [39]. Herein, we report a novel mesoporous COF with high surface area (600 m²/g), strong crystallinity and robust stability, and along with Cobalt-(dmg)2 Co-catalysts it exhibits excellent heterogeneous photocatalytic performances for CO2 reduction under visible-light irradiation. The efficiency of the photocatalytic protocol is seen very high in terms of formation of formic acid from CO2 reduction with 445 nm blue LED. According to our best knowledge, it will be the first report in the production of formic acid in combination with COF and Cobalt-DMG Co-catalysts under the visible light. The proposed catalytic cycle is in Fig. 1 . 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods Phloroglucinol, Hexamethylenetetramine (HMTA), p-toluenesulfonic acid (PTSA) were received from sigma Aldrich, India.Trifluoroacetic acid and Triethanolamine (TEOA) were purchased from E-Merk, India. 1,3,5-Triformylphloroglucinol (TFPG) was prepared from hexamethylenetetramine, dried phloroglucinol and trifluoroacetic acid following the previously reported literature procedure [50].The used ammine 2,6-diaminoanthraquinone (DAAQ) was obtained from sigma Aldrich, India and used without further purification. Cobalt-acetate and Dimethylglyoxime (DMG) were received from TCI chemicals, India. All other reagents such as Acetone and Acetonitrile used as solvents were bought from E-Merk, India and were used as received. All the reactions were performed using oven-dried glassware under ambient atmosphere unless otherwise mentioned. 2.2 Synthesis of mesoporous covalent organic framework (TFPG- DAAQ) Synthesis of TFPG-DAAQ COF was carried out by reacting 1,3,5-triformylphloroglucinol (TFPG) (189 mg, 0.9 mmol) and DAAQ (0.321 mg,1.35 mmol) using 7.5 mmol (1426.5 mg) of p-toluenesulfonic acid (PTSA) (Scheme 1 ). PTSA and DAAQ were uniformly mixed in a mortar-pestle and homogeneously grinded for 10 min to obtain a sticky salt. Then TFP (0.9 mmol, 189 mg) was added to the reaction mixture followed by further properly grinding for 15 min until it turned into dough like material. Few drops of deionized water based on requirement (100−200 μL) were added to make the mixture viscous. Then the COF precursors was taken in a Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated at 60 0C for first 6 h followed by 90 °C for another 10 h in static condition. The resulting TFPG- DAAQ COF was washed for 4–5 times using N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc) and then with excess acetone to remove the residues of the starting materials. The material was desiccated under vacuum for 24 h at room temperature to get the as-synthesized deep orange colored TFPG-DAAQ COF (80% isolated yield). 2.3 Procedure of formation of Formic acid using porous TFPG-DAAQ COF Photocatalyst The photocatalytic reduction of CO2 into Formic acid was performed by mixing of Triethanolamine (TEOA, 1 mmol, 0.133 mL), Cobalt-acetate (0.1 mmol, 25 mg), Dimethylglyoxime (0.2 mmol, 23 mg) in 5 mL Acetonitrile in presence of 10 mg of TFPG - DAAQ COF in a 25 mL round bottom flask. The reaction was allowed to run under irradiation of the blue LED light (445 nm) at room temperature for 4 h under continuous stirring (Figure S1). After completion of the reaction, TFPG - DAAQ COF was separated by filtration and the filtrate was analyzed by 1H and 13C NMR Spectra which confirms the formation of HCOOH. The yield of formic acid produced was detected by using UV-Visible spectrophotometer. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterisation 3.1.1 Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) Analysis The production of TFPG- DAAQ COF was established by PXRD analysis depicted in Fig. 2 . The characteristic peaks present at 3.5 and 27.1 correspond to the diffraction planes (100) and (001) respectively. The peak at 27.10 arises from the π-π stacking of (001) planes [51]. 3.1.2 FTIR analysis The FTIR spectra of TFPG, DAAQ, TFPG-DAAQ COF and catalyst are shown in Fig. 3 . The peaks at ∼1266 cm-1 and ∼1554 cm-1 are due to –(CN) and –(CC) bonds. The peaks in the FTIR spectra of DAAQ in the range of 3418-3200 cm-1 corresponds to –(NH) bonds, which are completely disappear in the FTIR spectra of TFPG-DAAQ COF confirming the complex formation between TFPG and DAAQ. The sharp peak at 1609 cm-1 in the spectra of TFPG-DAAQ COF is due to the –(CO) bonds. 3.1.3 UV-vis analysis Fig. 4 illustrates the solid state UV-visible absorbance spectra of the TFPG- DAAQ COF catalyst. The material showed broad absorption spectra in the range from 200 to 460 nm with a shoulder band at 493 nm. The absorption spectra include many transitions in the highly ordered conjugation systems [52]. 3.1.4 TGA analysis Fig. 5 illustrates the Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) curve of the TFPG- DAAQ COF catalyst. The plot suggests that the catalyst material is stable upto 4250C temperature. The small weight loss before 425 °C may be due to the elimination of surface adsorbed water and also due to the removal of other adsorbed gases from the porous framework. 3.1.5 Surface area measurement The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm of the TFPG-DAAQ COF catalystis depicted in Fig. 6 .The subsequent pore size distributions (PSD) resulting from the respective desorption data is given in the index of the isotherm plot. The TFPG-DAAQ COF sample has narrow and uniform pore size distribution with pore diameter 3.8 nm, which falls in the mesoporous region (2−50 nm). The estimated BET surface area and total pore volume of the TFPG-DAAQ COF are observed to be 600 m²/g and 0.81 cm3 g-1, respectively. 3.1.6 Microscopic Analysis The FESEM images (Fig. 7 of the TFPG-DAAQ COF showed disordered morphology of the sample. The elemental mapping analysis from the FESEM images of TFPG-DAAQ COF is shown in Fig. 8 a-d. Fig. 8b-d indicates the mapping images of carbon, nitrogen and oxygen, respectively. The interparticle porosity of the mesoporous COF material is confirmed by the TEM images (Fig. 9 ). Fig. 9a indicates the presence one dimensional fibrous structure of the material. These COF fibres are agglomerated and produce the disordered morphology, shown in Fig. 7. Additionally, the elemental composition is confirmed by the EDAX pattern of the sample, which goes well with the elemental mapping analysis (Fig. 10 ). 3.2 Catalytic studies For the initial study of photoreduction of CO2, the azine-based TFPG-DAAQ was chosen as the photo absorber, owing to their robustness and photoredox property. The ground state redox potential (E1/2 = 0.043 V vs Ag/AgCl) was determined from Cyclic Voltammetry (Figure S4(a), in SI) and using the emission maxima (Figure S6, in SI) of COF, we have calculated excited state redox potential value (EPS .+ /PS* = -2.157 V).The band gap, determined from CV analysis (Figure S4 in SI) and emission spectra (Figure S6) is 2.114 V along with conduction band potential 0.043 V and Valence band potential 2.157 V.We made an assumption based on the literatures, that introduction of Co based co-catalyst(E01/2 = -0.125 V vs Ag/AgCl, Figure S4(b) in SI), our catalytic system will work for the CO2 reduction under visible light (445 nm blue LED) at 25 °C [6b]. Various conditions for the reduction of CO2 to formic acid were examined and the results are summarized in Table 1 . The reaction was monitored by UV–vis spectroscopy with a calibration plot (See SI, figure S2). Irradiation (445 nm, 12 W/cm2) of a acetonitrile solution containing TFPG-DAAQ (10 mg), Co(dmg)2 (0.01 mol%) and TEOA (1 mmol) at room temperature produced formic acid with 125 TON (entry 11 in Table 1). The wavelength of irradiation was chosen as to selectively excite the TFPG-DAAQ but not Co(dmg)2 or product (formic acid) (Figure S5 in supporting information). Assuming the mechanism proposed in Fig. 1, the catalytic system produces formic acid with TON 125 per catalyst. It is worth note that the reaction proceeds, even under ambient sunlight, albeit at a much slower rate with approximately TON 36 after 6 h of exposure (entry 9 in Table 1). However, there was no such progress in the reaction without CO2 balloon, under open atmosphere (entry 10 in Table 1). Decreasing the catalyst and Co-catalyst loading by half, there was no significant drop in the TON (125) but switching the Co-catalyst from Co(dmg)2 to Co(oxim)2, a significantly reduced TON (50) was obtained. Therefore, all subsequent experiments were performed with 10 mg of catalyst, 0.1 mmol of Co(dmg)2 and 1 mmol of TEOA. Formation of formate was again confirmed with 1H and 13C NMR spectra in D2O monitoring at 0 h and at 4 h (Fig. 11 ). Without the light neither COF catalyst, TFPG-DAAQ nor Co(dmg)2 alone, nor a mixture of the two, were able to reduce CO2 into formate even at higher temperatures (entries 1–5 in Table 1). Similarly, irradiation of Co(dmg)2 along with CO2 did not result in product formation (entry 6 in Table 1). However, It is important to note that photoexcitation of TFPG-DAAQ in the presence of Co(dmg)2 but without TEOA (sacrificial electron source), the formation of formate was limited to approximately stoichiometric amounts with TON 15 (entry 8 in Table 1). All these control experiments demonstrate that the reaction is driven by photo-induced excitation of TFPG-DAAQ followed by electron transfer to Co(dmg)2 and regeneration of TFPG-DAAQ by sacrificial electron source TEOA. The reduction of CO2 to HCOOH with this catalytic system is solely dependent on light as demonstrated by monitoring HCOOH formation while modulating between light and dark reaction conditions at 30 min intervals (Fig. 12 ). In course of the 4 h experiment the formation of product increases during irradiation but remains almost constant in the dark. Additionally, while this reduction carried out with variable intensity of the light (3 W to 12 W), we found directly dependence of the amount of photo-flux on the reaction rate (Fig. 13 ). This light-modulated reduction of CO2 provides an extraordinary degree of control in formation of HCOOH as compared to traditional other catalytic reduction methodologies. The above result is in agreement with the proposed catalytic cycle depicted in Fig. 14 . Upon photo-excitation TFPG-DAAQ goes in the photo-excited state (EPS .+ /PS* = -2.157 V) and reduces Co(III) into Co(II) (E1/2 = -0.125 V vs Ag/AgCl)come back to ground state by SET by a oxidative quenching. After relaxation, accepting a single electron from sacrificial electron donor TEOA(E1/2 = 0.045 V vs Ag/AgCl), it generates TFPG-DAAQ which can then, upon excitation, undergoes additional reaction cycles reduces CO2 to HCOOH and itself gets oxidised into Co(III) which can go back to Co(II) by getting reduced by photo-excited TFPG-DAAQ. 3.3 Recyclability of TFPG- DAAQ COF catalyst After the catalytic run, the COF, TFPG-DAAQ was filtered and washed several times with acetonitrile. After drying, it was further used as the photocatalyst for next cycle and we found no prominent change in its activity in terms of TON. So, this recycling study was repeated upto 5 times without significant decrease in the activity (Table 2 ). This study indicates the industrial applicability and scalability of the COF, TFPG-DAAQ as the photocatalyst in the reduction of CO2 in formate. There were not prominent changes in the IR spectra of fresh and reused TFPG-DAAQ (Figure S8 in SI). There was also no significant change in the PXRD pattern of reused catalyst (Figure S9 in SI). The pore size distribution plot of the reused catalyst (Figure S10) suggested that there was small decrease in peak pore diameter (3.24 nm), which was may be due to blocking of pores by product material. This blocking of pores may cause the decrease in TON values for reused catalyst. 3.4 Heterogeneity test To know about the heterogeneous nature of the TFPG-DAAQ catalyst, a hot filtration test was carried out on the reduction of CO2 in formate. After 2 h of reaction TON = 100 was obtained. The catalyst was then filtered out from the reaction mixture and after that the reaction was performed for further 4 h in absence of the catalyst. It can be observed from Fig. 15 that the reaction was stopped at approximately TON = 100. Therefore no further reaction was happened after filtering out the catalyst. These observations strongly suggested that there was approximately no leaching out of composition elements from the TFPG-DAAQ catalyst during the reaction and the TFPG-DAAQ catalyst is completely heterogeneous in nature. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have demonstrated the photocatalytic reduction of CO2 in to formate by using COF as active photocatalyst along with Co(dmg)2 as the co-catalyst. The reaction goes with excellent TON under visible light and 1 atm CO2 pressure. Control experiments suggest that the reaction can’t proceed without the co-catalyst. The reaction does not occur in the absence of light even at elevated temperature and thus the reaction could readily be controlled by light alteration. Additionally, the photocatalyst is readily recoverable and reusable after completion of reaction without significant change in the catalytic activity. Declaration of Competing Interest We do hereby declare that there is no conflict of interest for the publication of this manuscript. coredata.dc:description: We demonstrate the photocatalytic reduction of CO2 into HCOOH using mesoporous Covalent Organic Framework (COF) as the active photocatalyst, Co(dmg)2 as co-catalyst with Triethanolamine (TEOA) as sacrificial electron source under atmospheric pressure. Greater than 125 TON is achieved with 10 mg catalyst. The reaction cycle is dependent on the use of co-catalyst, Co(dmg)2 and sacrificial electron donor (TEOA). The reaction does not occur in the absence of light (445 nm) and can readily be controlled by light intensity alternation. We also demonstrate that a TON of 36 can be obtained with use of sunlight using the catalytic cycle. These results open the door to an entirely new class of protocol for photocatalytic reduction of CO2 using COF and Co(dmg)2 as co-catalyst under visible light.
coredata.dc:title: Mesoporous covalent organic framework: An active photo-catalyst for formic acid synthesis through carbon dioxide reduction under visible light
